intro: Arceuthobium opuntioides, commonly known as the Indian knobby mistletoe, is a parasitic plant that attaches to the stems of cacti, particularly species of Opuntia. It lacks true leaves and roots, relying entirely on its host for nutrients and water. The plant produces small, white, fleshy berries that contain seeds dispersed by animals. Its unique growth form and specialized relationship with cacti make it an interesting subject in ecological studies. Due to its parasitic nature, it can significantly impact the health of its host plants if left unchecked.
